. "Embu," as it is often referred to, is also knowns as Land of the Arts or, simply, Embu of the Arts. The name appeared in years 60´s, when a strong movement characterized for the primitive art and the influence of the hippie culture in the city. 
Painters, artist, and artesoes have elected the city as the landmark of the Brazilian culture.
indigenous settlement, founded by jesuits between 1555-1559. The

church, still present in the city, was constructed in the second half of the XVII century.

The peaceful town would start to change in 1920, when the painter Cássio M'Boy, a lover of the
lifestyle, arrived in Embu. Cássio earned an international award in

in 1939, and afterwards, Embu started receiving an influx of artists, like Assis, Sakai, Gama, Solano Trindade and Ana Moysés.

In the end of the 60s, hippies started the tradition of the Open Arts Fair in the city, that persists in the weekends and holidays until nowadays. Finally, in 2011, Embu officially changed name to
Embu das Artes is a 40-min drive from downtown

( BR-116) leaves São Paulo in the direction of Curitiba, as you pass Taboão da Serra then Itapecerica da Serra. It can be easily accessed by taking Av. Francisco Morato, in São Paulo, and following the signs to Taboão da Serra.
Embu das Artes can also be accessed from São Paulo by metropolitan buses (EMTU)
, that depart from some metro stations including Tietê, Anhangabaú and Capão Redondo. These buses are cheap (most cost R$3-4) but not very practical, as some take longer than 2 hours to get to Embu.
The area of interest to a visitor is the city center, which can be easily explored on foot.

value: File:Igreja Nossa Senhora do Rosário em Embu das Artes.JPG
Conjunto Jesuítico Nossa Senhora do Rosário

content=Occupying all the central area of the city, the traditional open air fair, that happens since 1969, invites the visitor to a journey to the Brazilian colonial period. The 462 expositors are divided in the sections of plastic arts, ornamental artes, plants and typical foods. Undoubtly the highlight of a visit to Embu das Artes.
address=Rua Rebolo Gonzáles, 185, Vila Cercado Grande
content=Small chapel designed by the artist Helaine Malca and decorated by José Luiz Alemãn.
address=Between Rua da Matriz and Rua Nossa Sra. do Rosário
content=Colonial-style chapel constructed in 1934, containing an image of Saint Lazarus made by the city's legendary artist Cássio M'Boy, and the statue of Christ crafted by Zé Santeiro.
name=Conjunto Jesuítico Nossa Senhora do Rosário
content=A national heritage site, the XVII century construction is composed by the
church and an old jesuit residence, currently a sacred art museum, containing religious sculptures from the XVII-XIX centuries.
address=Rua Rebolo Gonzáles, 185, Vila Cercado Grande
content=Museum of art dedicated to the Japanese origin farmer and artist Tadakiyo Sakai, considered as one of the greatest terracotta sculptors of Brazil.
content=Nice public park with a large lake, for a relaxing stroll after shopping in the city center.

Works of art and handcrafts produced by local artists/artesans can be bought both at the open air fair and at shops in the Center. In the shops you can also buy handmade furniture and antiquities.
Embu das Artes' speciality dish is the
dish consisting of roasted piglet with dried and fried skin. The city center offers plenty of options of snackbars and restaurants.

value: address=Avenida Elias Yazbek, 1401, Praça da Lagoa
content=An open fair food court equipped with tables and chairs, where you can prove snacks and local food in 24 kiosks.
restaurant, one of the most traditional of Embu das Artes. Its speciality is the
content=Restaurant with mixed Brazilian and international food.
(German dish) and others. All-you-can-eat pasta on sundays.
content=Bar and club with four different environments, playing an ecletic selection of music. Live shows during the evening.
